title: Cleaner tried to sue school after vacuum cleaner gave her a static shock
text:
Renata Plawska Czerepak fell down the stairs and suffered a bad back after being shocked while working at St Paul’s boys’ school (Picture: Champion News)

A cleaner tried to sue a £57,000-a-year boarding school claiming she had been electrocuted by a vacuum cleaner.

Renata Plawska-Czerepak said she was knocked out cold, fell down a flight of stairs and injured her spine while working at St Paul’s boys’ school in London.

Her lawyer tried to claim that the vacuum cleaner’s wiring was faulty and, as a result, her workplace was unsafe.

However, a judge has now ruled that the 45-year-old experienced a static electric shock, rather than electrocution, and threw out her claim.

Renata Plawska Czerepak wanted compensation of more than £5,000 (Picture: Champion News)

Mrs Plawska-Czerepak had been holding the metal section of the machine whilst cleaning the stairs at the school’s theatre when she was jolted.

The ‘surprise’ effect threw her off balance and she toppled backwards down three steps, banging her face in the fall and being briefly knocked unconscious, she told the Mayors and City of London Court.

She said: ‘It was only a mild shock, but I got scared and fell backwards.’

Mrs Plawska-Czerepak, of Wembley, north-west London, said that during the November 2014 accident she strained her spine.

It ignited previously dormant back problems and court documents stated she has now been left with lasting lower back pain.

But after a trial, Judge Alan Saggerson ruled against the cleaner, dashing her hopes of more than £5,000 compensation.

The elite boarding school St Paul’s at Barnes in south London (Picture: Champion News)

He accepted her as an honest witness but added: ‘I reject the allegation that it was a pure electric shock and conclude that this was a static electric shock which took her by surprise, and as a result she fell back down the stairs and suffered injury.’

He also declined to accept that the fall had knocked her out.

St Paul’s School, which was founded over 500 years ago, has a reputation for academic excellence.

It has produced a string of famous old boys over the centuries – including Samuel Pepys, Field Marshal Lord Montgomery and more recently the broadcaster, Dan Snow.

It is set in grounds on the banks of the Thames and education and boarding fees come to around £57,000 per year.
